page.topic: How to Create and Add a Sub-theme

description.p: Sub-themes are reusable style definitions for controls.

discussion.p: Sub-themes allow you to create one or more reusable 'looks' for controls - such as buttons or Lists. In a sub-theme definition, basic styling as well as behaviors (hover, visited, active, focus, etc) can be defined for a control.

tip.p: For a great guide to pseudo-elements and pseudo-classes, check out *[extlink:https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2016/05/an-ultimate-guide-to-css-pseudo-classes-and-pseudo-elements/]*.

description.p: The sub-theme is applied to a control using its *[ui:Sub-theme]* property. Multiple sub-themes can be created for the same control type, however only one sub-theme can be assigned to a control at design time.
To create a sub-theme, use the Sub-theme Builder. Sub-themes can be created in several locations:

item.name: In the Sub-theme Builder accessed via a control's *[ui:Sub-theme]* property
In the component settings when defining Style Tweaks

description.p: While sub-themes can be defined directly using a source editor (JavaScript and CSS), it's easiest to start by copying an existing sub-theme and then making your own modifications. In the Sub-theme Builder, you can optionally select a sub-theme to copy when creating a new sub-theme. All items that support sub-themes have at least one sub-theme, "base", defined in the styles that ship with Alpha Anywhere. Some controls, such as List controls (listbox) and button controls (button) have multiple sub-themes defined in the styles that ship with Alpha Anywhere.
To create a sub-theme, it's easiest to start by copying an existing sub-theme definition and then adding your own class definitions.

note.p: The following steps show you how to create a sub-theme using the Web Style Builder. Sub-themes can also be created from within the UX Builder using the [Style sub-theme and CSS 'tweaks'].

description.p: Open the Web Style Builder from the Web Projects Control Panel.
Select one of the style sheets that support sub-themes. Styles that support sub-themes include "Alpha", "iOS7", "AndroidDark", and "AndroidLight".

note.p: You can create your own style that supports sub-themes as well by copying an existing style sheet and editing it using the Web Style Builder.

description.p: On the Code tab in the Web Style Builder, locate the *[ui:Select part...]* menu.

Select the part for which you would like to create a new sub-theme. Every part in the list can have a sub-theme. The list below explains what each listed part corresponds to in the UX Component (this is not a comprehensive list):

item.name: Accordion
item.description: Tab Control rendered as an accordion

item.name: Tab
item.description: The Tab control - styles the tab pane

item.name: Tab Band
item.description: The Tab control - styles the tabs

item.name: Date Picker
item.description: The Date Picker for a Text Box control.

item.name: Time Picker
item.description: The Time Picker for a Text Box control.

item.name: Edit
item.description: Text Box, Textarea, and Dropdown Box controls.

item.name: Edit Button Group
item.description: The in-control buttons shown in a Text Box control.

item.name: Button Dropdown
item.description: A Button control with [Has dropdown icon] enabled.

item.name: Button Split
item.description: A Button control with [Has dropdown icon] and [Display as split button] enabled.

description.p: After you select a Part, you can optionally select a *[ui:Sub-theme]* to copy. Every Part has at least one sub-theme - "base". In the image below, the base sub-theme will be copied to a new sub-theme called "orangeButtons".

Click *[ui:Create]* to create the sub-theme. This will take you back to the Code tab in the Web Theme Builder with the new sub-theme selected. Both CSS and Sass can be used to define the style for the sub-theme. Several tools exist to make it easier to add colors and variables to your style. To insert a color, select *[ui:Insert Color]* from the *[ui:Add Variable]* menu.

The *[ui:Color Picker]* includes multiple tools for selecting colors, including Fan Decks and the ability to select colors from an existing image. The *[ui:Palettes]* tab is where you can create and save color collections.
Once you have finished defining your new sub-theme, it's ready to be used. Click the *[ui:Save]* icon in the toolbar to save your changes.
Sub-themes are assigned to controls using the Sub-theme property. Let's assign the sub-theme created in the previous section to a button in a UX Component.
Open the UX Builder and go to the Controls pane.
Select a control to the UX that you built the sub-theme for. Then, click the [...] smart field for the *[ui:Sub-theme]* property for the control.
Select the new sub-theme from the *[ui:Select Sub-theme]* dialog and click OK to assign the sub-theme. Open the component in Live or Working Preview to preview your change.
